head.title: Oh, the Songs Shine Bright In Some Old Kentucky Homes

hedline.hl1: Oh, the Songs Shine Bright In Some Old Kentucky Homes
hedline.hl2: Oh, the Songs Shine Bright in Some Old Kentucky Homes

block.p: Many, many strings are plucked in ''The Rhythm of My Soul: Kentucky Roots Music,'' a documentary by Roger Sherman tonight on PBS, but all that boinging never really convinces you that Kentucky has anything more to boast about musically than assorted other states. The film feels like an attempt to cut into the dominance of Nashville, and though it does introduce some swell pickers and fiddlers you've probably never heard of, in general Nashville has nothing to worry about.

The film's premise is that an inordinate number of Kentuckians sit around their living rooms playing guitars, fiddles and banjos. ''People can't go to the movies every night,'' notes Bo McCarty, a local bluegrass authority, ''but you can play your guitar every night.''

The film feels like an attempt to cut into the dominance of Nashville, and though it does introduce some swell pickers and fiddlers you've probably never heard of, in general Nashville has nothing to worry about.

The film's premise is that an inordinate number of Kentuckians sit around their living rooms playing guitars, fiddles and banjos. ''People can't go to the movies every night,'' notes Bo McCarty, a local bluegrass authority, ''but you can play your guitar every night.''

Maybe, but the same claim could probably be made in Mississippi or Tennessee or West Virginia. And a lot of the insights offered by the musicians who flit through the film -- they first became interested in music by singing in church! -- could just as easily have come from a Chicago bluesman or Broadway diva.

So the film is more cheerleading than revelation. Mr. Sherman, though, does find a few genuinely entertaining players, none more so than the Carriere Family, fiddlers extraordinaire. And occasionally in its meandering survey of country, bluegrass, gospel and mountain music in the state, the film throws in interesting tidbits, like, for instance, that fiddle players along the Ohio River were influenced by the classical violinists they heard on passing riverboats. But the film, though pleasant and tuneful enough, is ultimately a hodgepodge that doesn't quite prove its thesis.
The Rhythm of My Soul Kentucky Roots Music Tonight on most PBS stations (check local listings).
Roger Sherman, producer, director and cinematographer; Meredith McGuire, associate producer; Kris Liem, editor; Scott Connolly, sound. A production of Florentine Films/Sherman Pictures.
